Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Thumb and Index Finger Techniques for Laryngeal Mask Airway Insertion

Participants.evidence: Participants were 40 American Society of Anesthesiologists grade I and II patients aged 18-60 years. Exclusion criteria included risk of aspiration, limited mouth opening, and certain medical conditions.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomly allocated into two groups: Group I (Index Finger) and Group T (Thumb Insertion)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of the thumb insertion technique compared to the conventional index finger technique for inserting the silicone laryngeal mask airway (LMA) Classicâ„¢

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was ease of insertion, assessed immediately post-insertion.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using sealed numbered envelopes.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Patients were randomly allocated into two groups: Group I (Index Finger) and Group T (Thumb Insertion), with 20 patients each.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean time for insertion was 29.00 seconds for Group I and 34.00 seconds for Group T, with no statistical significance.
